current_fact.fact_text: Across several 28 Decembers, from Röntgen’s X-rays to the Lumière brothers’ films, humans have found new ways to see the invisible and capture fleeting moments—bones beneath skin, trains in motion, city life on celluloid. These breakthroughs turned light itself into a tool for probing reality and telling stories.

episode.title: Sedna FM #02 - Destination Sedna

current_fact.match_reason: A day marked by new ways of seeing aligns with an exploratory ‘destination’ episode: shifting musical lenses like scientific instruments, inviting listeners to perceive familiar worlds in strange new light.

queue.fact_text: Layered together, the events of 28 December trace a strangely human constellation: scientific leaps and cinematic firsts, earthquakes and deportations, political trailblazers and record-shattering athletes, environmental laws and aerial tragedies. It’s a reminder that any given date on Earth’s calendar holds multitudes—joy, risk, cruelty, imagination—all orbiting the same Sun.

episode.title: Sedna FM #01 - November Bomb
episode.description: The first Family & Friends radio episode from Yasmin Sarbaoui and Gaia Parolini. Where it all began — a life soundtrack that launched Sedna FM into the universe. Raw, heartfelt, and full of the energy that defines everything that followed.
songs: Canserbero - De la vida como pelicula, tragedia, comedia y ficcion

queue.match_reason: A closing, panoramic reflection on everything that happened ‘today’ pairs with Sedna’s very first episode—a big-bang life soundtrack that, like the date itself, holds many moods and stories at once.

published.fact_text: On 28 December 1895, Wilhelm Röntgen published the first paper describing a mysterious new kind of radiation that could see through flesh but not bone. His ghostly images of hands and metal objects stunned the scientific world and transformed medicine almost overnight.

episode.title: Morning Drops #05 - Electric Shock
episode.description: An energizing episode with electrifying sounds to wake you up and get you moving. High energy tracks that deliver a jolt of musical electricity to start your day.

published.match_reason: Röntgen’s discovery of X-rays was literally a new kind of invisible electricity; a high-voltage breakthrough pairs well with an episode themed around electrifying shocks and charged guitar energy.

published.fact_text: Also on 28 December 1895, the Lumière brothers held the first public screening for a paying audience in a Paris café basement. The short, flickering films of workers leaving a factory and trains arriving were enough to make some viewers duck for cover, convinced the locomotive would burst out of the screen.

episode.title: Morning Drops #12 - 80's Club
episode.description: Starting with a Monday evening in Munich — a few drinks, friends, and landing in an 80s dance party. From Donna Summer's hypnotic pulse, to Depeche Mode's bright synthpop, Ken Laszlo's Italo Disco romance, and Mylène Farmer's darker theatrical world. Four songs, four corners of the 80s — connected by the machines that changed how we dance.
songs: Depeche Mode - Just Can't Get Enough

published.match_reason: The first cinema audience sat in a café and watched moving images powered by new machines; this 80s-club set celebrates another era when machines and screens reshaped how people gathered to watch, dance, and feel hypnotized by light and sound.

published.fact_text: On 28 December 1908, a massive magnitude 7.1 earthquake struck the Strait of Messina between Sicily and mainland Italy. In less than a minute it flattened whole neighborhoods, triggered a tsunami, and killed as many as 80,000 people, making it one of Europe’s deadliest quakes.

episode.title: Morning Drops #39 - Moving Meditation
episode.description: An episode inspired by how travel helps us see more clearly. Stepping into new places opens the mind, shifts perspective. The music moves through balearic warmth, boogie grooves, world and latin-folk influences, and touches of new wave — a selection built to follow the quiet changes that happen when you're out of your usual rhythm.
songs: España Circo Este - Dormo poco e sogno molto
Talking Heads - This Must Be the Place (Naive Melody)

published.match_reason: A seismic catastrophe on Italy’s southern coast meets an introspective, travel-themed episode with Italian folk-rock colors—inviting reflection on how landscapes, and lives, can shift in an instant.

published.fact_text: On 28 December 893, a powerful earthquake destroyed the Armenian city of Dvin, then a thriving medieval capital and trading hub. The disaster reshaped the region’s political and cultural landscape, leaving ruins that still tell stories of a lost urban world.

episode.title: Morning Drops #16 - The Sound of Tuareg
episode.description: A journey into the sound of the Tuareg: from traditional chants and desert rituals to the electrified rhythms of exile and resistance. Music shaped by sand, memory, and survival.

published.match_reason: An ancient city wiped out by tectonic forces resonates with Tuareg desert blues—music born from harsh landscapes, memory, and the resilience of cultures that endure after cities fall.

published.fact_text: On 28 December 1902, the Syracuse Athletic Club beat the New York Philadelphians 5–0 in what is considered the first indoor professional American football game, played under the roof of Madison Square Garden. Fans watched a rough outdoor sport squeezed into an arena lit by new electric lamps, an early experiment in turning stadium sport into enclosed spectacle.

episode.title: Morning Drops #17 - Steel City
episode.description: Gaia takes us on a short trip through Sheffield's sounds — from electronic textures to raw guitars and sharp storytelling. Four tracks, one city, different edges of the same story.
songs: The Human League - The Sound Of The Crowd

published.match_reason: An industrial-age indoor football experiment in New York fits with a city-focused episode about Sheffield’s steel and stadium-ready sounds, all about how urban spaces reshape noise, play, and crowds.

published.fact_text: On 28 December 1835, Seminole leader Osceola led his warriors in Florida into what became the Second Seminole War against the United States. The conflict was fueled by resistance to forced removal from their lands, and Osceola’s guerrilla tactics turned the swamps and hammocks into a maze for the U.S. Army.

episode.title: Morning Drops #16 - The Sound of Tuareg
episode.description: A journey into the sound of the Tuareg: from traditional chants and desert rituals to the electrified rhythms of exile and resistance. Music shaped by sand, memory, and survival.

published.match_reason: Osceola’s fight against displacement mirrors the Tuareg narratives of land, resistance, and survival; the desert blues here becomes an echo of another indigenous struggle to stay rooted.

published.fact_text: On 28 December 1918, while imprisoned in Holloway, Irish revolutionary Constance Markievicz became the first woman ever elected to the British House of Commons. She never took her seat in London, instead honoring Sinn Féin’s policy of abstention and helping to found Ireland’s revolutionary parliament.

episode.title: Morning Drops #04 - Bars With Balls
episode.description: Yasmin dives into Women's Day through the voices of four incredible female rappers. Morning fire from the magic planet of Sedna FM — move your hands up and down with us. Hip hop culture through a feminine lens.
songs: Little Simz - Point and Kill (feat. Obongjayar)

published.match_reason: Markievicz broke a political barrier for women under extreme pressure; an episode centered on powerful female voices in rap amplifies that same fearless energy and insistence on being heard.

published.fact_text: On 28 December 1941, Operation Anthropoid began—the daring Allied mission to assassinate Reinhard Heydrich, one of the most powerful and feared Nazi officials. Two Czech agents were parachuted into occupied territory, setting in motion one of World War II’s most audacious resistance operations.

episode.title: Morning Drops #36 - Women of Rock
episode.description: A tribute to the women who shaped the sound of rock, the ones who picked up a guitar and refused to ask for permission. The conversation unfolds in Italian, led by Gaia and her father. A dialogue between generations and a reminder that the pulse of rock has always belonged to anyone brave enough to play it loud. Distortion, rhythm, freedom.
songs: Joan Jett & The Blackhearts - I Love Rock 'n Roll

published.match_reason: A high-risk act of resistance calls for distorted guitars and defiant voices; the Women of Rock episode channels the same raw courage and refusal to submit to authoritarian power.

published.fact_text: On 28 December 1943, Soviet authorities launched Operation Ulussy—the mass deportation of the Kalmyk people to Siberia and Central Asia. Entire communities were loaded into cattle cars in winter, accused of collective treason, and forbidden to return to their homeland for more than a decade.

episode.title: Morning Drops #14 - Slow Planet
episode.description: A pause. A quiet return to slower rhythms, sparked by a live set under the summer sky. A moment to breathe and settle into the week.

published.match_reason: The brutality of forced deportation contrasts starkly with the gentle, spacious textures of Slow Planet—offering a sonic space to slow down, remember, and contemplate lives uprooted by state violence.

published.fact_text: On 28 December 1944, Maurice “Rocket” Richard became the first player in NHL history to score eight points in a single game, with five goals and three assists. His explosive performance cemented his myth as a player whose speed and intensity seemed to bend hockey’s limits.

episode.title: Morning Drops #05 - Electric Shock
episode.description: An energizing episode with electrifying sounds to wake you up and get you moving. High energy tracks that deliver a jolt of musical electricity to start your day.

published.match_reason: Richard’s record-breaking night on the ice feels like a lightning strike in sport history; a blast of electric blues-rock mirrors that sense of speed, surge, and pure kinetic energy.

published.fact_text: On 28 December 1956, Chin Peng, David Marshall, and Tunku Abdul Rahman met in Baling, Malaya, trying to negotiate an end to the Malayan Emergency. The talks ultimately failed, but the meeting brought guerrilla leaders, colonial authorities, and future national leaders face-to-face at a pivotal moment in Southeast Asia’s decolonization.

episode.title: Morning Drops #35 - Thailand
episode.description: Recorded in Koh Samui, Thailand, where Yasmin and her friend Patricia spent more than two intense weeks training Muay Thai and Western boxing. Between sweat, rhythm, and sea breeze, they share reflections on discipline, friendship, and the beauty of movement - with a soundtrack that connects Thai sounds to the flow of daily practice.
songs: Burna Boy - Cheat on Me (feat. Dave)

published.match_reason: The Baling Talks sit within a broader Southeast Asian story of conflict, negotiation, and discipline; an episode shaped by Thai training camps and regional sounds offers an atmospheric regional echo to this political standoff.

published.fact_text: On 28 December 1958, the NFL Championship between the Baltimore Colts and the New York Giants went into the league’s first sudden-death overtime. The dramatic finish, watched by millions on television, became known as “The Greatest Game Ever Played” and helped catapult American football into a national obsession.

episode.title: Morning Drops #03 - Space Shift
episode.description: Gaia invites you to shift your mindset with a simple yet powerful reflection: What if we saw emptiness not as a void but as space to create? An energising and feel-good selection of tracks, the perfect way to ease into your day and set the tone for the week ahead.
songs: Willy J Healey - Woke Up Smiling
The Strokes - You Only Live Once

published.match_reason: A tense, open-ended overtime suddenly becomes a space where anything can happen, just as Space Shift reframes emptiness as potential—both moments where uncertainty turns into a stage for defining moves.

published.fact_text: On 28 December 1967, Muriel Siebert became the first woman to own a seat on the New York Stock Exchange, breaking through one of Wall Street’s most exclusive boys’ clubs. She had to secure backing from male colleagues and negotiate a loan just to buy her way onto the trading floor.

episode.title: Morning Drops #34 - Soul Sisters
episode.description: A tribute to four iconic voices — women who have shaped the way we listen, feel, and move. Each track carries a different kind of presence: one that holds you, one that questions, one that grounds, and one that lets go. An energy that is soulful, raw, and unapologetically feminine.
songs: Grace Jones - Walking in the Rain
Aretha Franklin - A Rose Is Still a Rose

published.match_reason: Siebert’s lone figure on the NYSE floor fits perfectly with an episode celebrating women who carved out space in male-dominated industries, all powered by unapologetically strong female voices.

published.fact_text: On 28 December 1972, the United States held what was scheduled to be its final day for drafting young men through the Selective Service System. A national day of mourning for Harry S. Truman closed many federal offices, meaning about 300 men who were supposed to report simply never did—and then the draft was never restarted.

episode.title: Morning Drops #27 - Nomophobia
episode.description: Yasmin reflects on what happened when she recently lost her phone and why it felt freeing. A dive into the psychology of our relationship with smartphones: from nomophobia (the fear of being without a phone), to digital burnout and cognitive overload, to the surprising benefits of boredom and the brain's default mode network. An invitation to rethink how we connect and disconnect.

published.match_reason: A generation’s relationship with the state and compulsory service quietly shifts on a day of bureaucratic absence; Nomophobia similarly explores how our bonds to big unseen systems (like tech) can dissolve or loosen when the connection suddenly breaks.

published.fact_text: On 28 December 1973, U.S. President Richard Nixon signed the Endangered Species Act into law. It gave unprecedented protection to threatened plants and animals, recognizing that human activity could push entire species to the brink—and that governments could choose to pull them back.

episode.title: Morning Drops #40 - Diving With Orcas
episode.description: Yasmin's friend Caroline takes us beyond the polar circle, into the Arctic waters of Norway, where orcas and humpback whales gather each winter. A personal journey shaped by a quiet obsession with orcas, from Patagonia to the icy fjords of the north. The soundscape moves gently between cinematic swells and soft, rhythmic pulses — echoing the cold light of Arctic mornings and the grace of underwater encounters.

published.match_reason: A landmark law to protect vulnerable species connects naturally with an episode about orcas and whales, immersing listeners in the fragile beauty that such legislation hopes to preserve.

published.fact_text: On 28 December 1989, a magnitude 5.6 earthquake hit Newcastle, New South Wales, one of Australia’s largest urban quakes. Thirteen people were killed and hundreds injured, revealing how even moderate seismic events can be devastating when they strike cities not built with quakes in mind.

episode.title: Morning Drops #15 - Unfreezing
episode.description: A short, honest Morning Drop with no grand theme — just four tracks, a bit of voice, and the decision to not wait for the 'right' moment. Room to breathe today.
songs: Jane Birkin & Serge Gainsbourg - Je t’aime… moi non plus
Bernard Badie - In Love (DJ Quad's at Night Mix)

published.match_reason: A sudden jolt to an unsuspecting city mirrors the idea of being shaken out of paralysis; Unfreezing offers gentle, pressure-and-release rhythms that feel like thawing after an unexpected shock.

published.fact_text: On 28 December 2006, forces of Somalia’s Transitional Federal Government, backed by Ethiopian troops, entered Mogadishu largely unopposed, ousting the Islamic Courts Union. The swift capture of the capital reshuffled power in the Horn of Africa and plunged Somalia into another cycle of conflict.

episode.title: Evening Flows #01 - Yasmin - Crescendo in the Medina
episode.description: The first Evening Flow episode comes from Yasmin. It starts deep in the medina, slow, mysterious, textured, and grows into a liberating dance across sub-Saharan landscapes. A journey through ambient soundscapes, Arabic melodies, Afro-Latin rhythms, and funky highlife grooves.
songs: David Visan & Carlos Campos - Crystal Heart
Evan Mars - Ya Zareef Al Tool
Dele Sosimi & Medlar - You No Fit Touch Am (Medlar Remix)

published.match_reason: The battle for Mogadishu sits within a wider story of East African and Islamic cultural crossroads; this medina-to-sub-Saharan sonic journey reflects the region’s layered identities behind the headlines of war.

published.fact_text: On 28 December 2009, a suicide bomber struck a Shia Ashura procession in Karachi, Pakistan, killing more than forty people. The attack targeted a sacred day of mourning, turning a religious ritual of grief and remembrance into a scene of sudden chaos.

episode.title: Morning Drops #14 - Slow Planet
episode.description: A pause. A quiet return to slower rhythms, sparked by a live set under the summer sky. A moment to breathe and settle into the week.

published.match_reason: Violence intruding on a ritual space creates a rupture that calls for stillness and reflection; Slow Planet’s meditative textures offer a counterpoint, a breathing space to process grief and fragility.

published.fact_text: On 28 December 2014, Indonesia AirAsia Flight 8501 crashed into the Karimata Strait en route from Surabaya to Singapore, killing all 162 people on board. Investigators later linked the disaster to a mix of technical failure and human factors in the cockpit, underscoring how complex systems can unravel in minutes.

episode.title: Morning Drops #33 - Immerse
episode.description: An analogy between diving, one of Gaia's great passions, and the act of immersing in life itself. A reflection on what happens when we go below the surface: when we let ourselves be fully present. From moments of calm suspension to warm, rhythmic flow, the selection moves like water — fluid, organic, and alive. An invitation to slow down, listen deeper, and float.
songs: Pino D'Angiò - Un Po' d'Uva e un Liquore

published.match_reason: An airliner vanishing into the sea invites somber thoughts about what lies beneath the surface; Immerse, with its water-like flow, offers a contemplative descent into depth and the unseen forces that carry us.

published.fact_text: On 28 December 2019, a truck bomb exploded at a busy checkpoint in Mogadishu, Somalia, killing at least 85 people and injuring many more. The attack, claimed by al-Shabaab, struck commuters and students, turning an everyday traffic bottleneck into a deadly blast zone.

episode.title: Morning Drops #23 - Morning Dubs
episode.description: Recorded while still processing Houghton Festival. One of the mornings there, waking up in the woods to a reggae DJ set — no phone signal, just trees, music, and loved ones. A slow selection of reggae, dub, and morning rhythms. Dubs instead of drops. Start your day slow — with space to breathe.
songs: The Gaylads - Joy in the Morning
King Tubby - King Tubby Meets the Rockers Uptown

published.match_reason: In the wake of urban terror and political violence, dub’s spacious, echoing sound has long been a language of mourning and resistance; Morning Dubs offers a slow, reflective counter-rhythm to the shock of such attacks.

published.fact_text: On 28 December 2006–2009’s Somali conflict timeline, the fall of Mogadishu was only one chapter; by 2019, the city was still living with the echoes of war, as seen in the truck bombing. These linked events show how a capital’s daily life can be repeatedly shattered and rebuilt under the shadow of militancy.

episode.title: Morning Drops #32 - A Weekend In London
episode.description: Recorded in London, marking a weekend reunion between Gaia and Yasmin. A selection inspired by London's energy, seen through the eyes of two inseparable friends — music from concerts, club nights, and long walks across town. Four tracks to ease you into the week at the right pace.
songs: Jimmy Castor Bunch - It's Just Begun
The Asphodells - Late Flowering Lust (Phil Kieran Remix)

published.match_reason: Juxtaposing Mogadishu’s fractured urban routine with a relaxed London weekend emphasizes how cities can embody both vulnerability and vibrant everyday life; this London episode, with African diasporic sounds, hints at global city-to-city connections.

published.fact_text: Throughout 28 December in different years, sport has quietly kept rewriting its own boundaries—from Maurice Richard’s eight-point game in 1944 to early indoor football at Madison Square Garden, to the NFL’s first sudden-death overtime in 1958. These moments show how games evolve through bold experiments and players who stretch what seems possible.

episode.title: Sedna FM #05 - On The Go - Zero Zero
